title: Attack Path Remediation Lab
subtitle: Blue-team workflows for closing BloodHound findings
prerequisites: Active Directory Enumeration & Attack Path Discovery
concepts: Short path vs choke point analysis
Automation with Azure AD and PowerShell
learning_objectives: Prioritise BloodHound findings using choke points and high-value assets
Execute remediation steps for common attack path patterns
Automate group membership and delegation clean-up with scripts
Communicate remediation progress and residual risk to stakeholders
Integrate remediation workflows into change management processes
Validate that remediation actions persist using continuous scanning

content_blocks.title: Think Like a Cartographer

content.text: You have a map of privilege paths—your job is to redraw the terrain. Approach remediation as an iterative cartography project: eliminate shortcuts, reinforce bridges, and document every change.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: You are redrawing the map to make attackers work harder.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Blue teams that succeed view BloodHound data as a living atlas of privilege.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which attack path pattern causes the most concern in your environment?

content_blocks.title: Remediation Workflow

content.text:
## P.A.T.H.
- **P**rioritise by blast radius and chokepoints.
- **A**ct by adjusting groups, delegation, and service accounts.
- **T**rack in change management systems with rollback plans.
- **H**arden long term through automation and monitoring.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Follow PATH to turn findings into lasting fixes.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Security engineers use PATH to brief leadership on remediation status.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: How will you measure the impact of each PATH iteration?

content_blocks.title: BloodHound for Blue Teams

content.resources:

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Observe how experienced defenders tackle privilege cleanup.
memory_aids: Note each script and add it to your toolkit

content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which automation idea will you pilot immediately?

content_blocks.title: TRIM Checklist

content.text:
### T.R.I.M.
- **T**ag high-risk edges.
- **R**emove unnecessary rights.
- **I**dentify replacement controls.
- **M**onitor for regression.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: TRIM keeps remediation focused on high-risk edges.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Teams incorporate TRIM into sprint checklists to avoid backlog sprawl.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which TRIM step needs stakeholder buy-in to succeed?

content_blocks.title: Field Example: Retail Privilege Cleanup

content.text: A retail enterprise used BloodHound choke point analysis to identify five privileged groups whose removal broke 70% of attack paths. Automations via PowerShell and Azure Automation enforced least privilege, and Defender for Identity alerts confirmed reduced attack surface.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Targeted cleanup yielded massive risk reduction.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Story adapted from a customer success case study.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What chokepoint in your environment could offer similar leverage?

content_blocks.title: Remediation Sprint Planning

content.text:
1. Select a high-risk attack path from a sample BloodHound export.
2. Document affected groups, computers, and delegation settings.
3. Draft remediation steps with rollback and communication plans.
4. Assign owners and due dates, then define verification queries.
5. Capture the sprint plan in your operations notebook.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Practise turning findings into a sprint backlog that sticks.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Blue teams run workshops like this to kick off remediation programmes.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which stakeholder needs to approve your plan before execution?

content_blocks.title: Teach Back the Cleanup

content.text:
### Reflect & Teach
- Summarise your remediation plan for a leadership audience.
- Record two metrics you will track to demonstrate progress (paths removed, privileged accounts reduced).
- Identify one automation or detection you will add to prevent regression.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Teaching the plan ensures stakeholders understand impact and safeguards.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Monthly metrics reviews rely on concise storytelling like this.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Who will you brief on these improvements and when?

post_assessment.question: Why focus on choke points when prioritising attack path remediation?
options: They are easy to remove without change control
They represent edges whose removal breaks many attack paths at once
They reduce the need for documentation
post_assessment.explanation: Choke points provide high leverage; fixing them collapses multiple privilege chains simultaneously.

post_assessment.question: Which step ensures remediation work remains auditable?
options: Skipping change requests for faster progress
Tracking changes with owners, rollback plans, and verification queries
Deleting BloodHound exports after work is complete
post_assessment.explanation: Documenting owners, rollback, and verification enables auditability and consistent execution.

post_assessment.question: How can automation aid attack path remediation?
options: Automation replaces the need for human oversight
Scripts can enforce least privilege, validate changes, and detect regressions
Automation should only run once at the end of the project
Automation keeps findings hidden from leadership
post_assessment.explanation: Automation helps enforce desired state, validate results, and surface regressions for follow-up.
